title: How to use my addictive personality as an advantage - Quora

response.answer_text: I have a manic personality for the most part. Addictive is not a wrong word. An addictive personality to me can focus on a particular area bed a drug gambling or success. For me it required a need to balance that with life in general but as far as business I wouldn’t have traded my manic/ addictive personality.

I damaged my brain in a way that effects my memories and it also stunted the growth of my frontal cortex so I also suffer very sever ADHD. In relationships I often get too attatched way to fast and I am very loyal right off the bat which makes for very violent emotional trauma by even the smallest of break-ups. Shit I might not even have to be dating the person if I just like the way they look I get extremely infatuated and I don’t focus on anything but them. So in my experience of having a severely addictive personality no good can come of it.

Many years of research has failed to identify any cluster of traits that commonly occur among people who have had a substance or alcohol use disorder. There is no such thing as an “addictive personality”. It’s a myth. The only unifying factor that has been found is a tendency to be slightly higher in impulsivity, and even that doesn’t by any means apply to all people. When we label ourselves and others we do great harm. We mislead ourselves about our true nature and potential. We typecast ourselves and live out lives based on misconceptions of what we are “really” like. Or worse yet, we typecast and demonise others.

Having an addictive personality doesn't definitely mean that a person will become an addict (to drugs, for example). An addictive persinoty without having a harmful addiction could potentially result in someone being super focused on a positive thing, like finding new treatments for disease. I don't know if I have an addictive personality, but I probably do, as I am a recovering alcoholic. I don't wish addiction on anyone, but working hard inovercoming it has had hugely positive effects on my life and personal well being.
